data.name: XGraphicDevice
desc: This interface provides access to a graphic device, such as a printer, or a screen device.
Every canvas (

For a typical windowing system, the graphic device is equivalent to a distinct OS window, with its own clipped output area, fullscreen and double-buffering attributes. That is, even if one can have multiple canvases per system window, they all share the same graphic device and thus e.g. fullscreen state. If the OS restrictions are in such a way that fullscreen or double-buffering is screen-exclusive, i.e. that per screen, only one object can have this state, it might even be that all windows on the screen share a common graphic device.

methods.name: createCompatibleAlphaBitmap
desc: Create a bitmap with alpha channel whose memory layout and sample model is compatible to the graphic device.

methods.name: createCompatibleBezierPolyPolygon
desc: Create a Bezier poly-polygon which can internally use device-optimized representations already.

methods.name: createCompatibleBitmap
desc: Create a bitmap whose memory layout and sample model is compatible to the graphic device.

methods.name: createCompatibleLinePolyPolygon
desc: Create a line poly-polygon which can internally use device-optimized representations already.

methods.name: createVolatileAlphaBitmap
desc: Create a volatile bitmap with alpha channel that is usable with this graphic device.

A volatile bitmap's difference in comparison to a plain bitmap (e.g. generated via createCompatibleBitmap()) is the fact that its content might vanish at any point in time (making any operation with them produce a VolatileContentDestroyedException). The benefit, on the other hand, is that they might be easy to hardware-accelerate on certain platforms, without the need to keep a safety copy of the content internally.

methods.name: createVolatileBitmap
desc: Create a volatile bitmap that is usable with this graphic device.

A volatile bitmap's difference in comparison to a plain bitmap (e.g. generated via createCompatibleBitmap()) is the fact that its content might vanish at any point in time (making any operation with them produce a VolatileContentDestroyedException). The benefit, on the other hand, is that they might be easy to hardware-accelerate on certain platforms, without the need to keep a safety copy of the content internally.

methods.name: enterFullScreenMode
desc: Enter or leave the fullscreen mode, if possible.
The return value denotes the success of the operation.

methods.name: getBufferController
desc: Query the controller for multi buffering functionality on this graphic device.
If there is no such functionality available, the NULL reference is returned.

methods.name: getDeviceColorSpace
desc: Query the color space interface for this graphic device.
This is to be used when interpreting or setting device color values.

methods.name: getParametricPolyPolygonFactory
desc: Get a reference to this device's parametric polygon factory.
Available services (all canvas implementations should provide this minimal set, though are free to add more; just check the getAvailableServiceNames() on the returned interface):

methods.name: getPhysicalResolution
desc: Query the physical resolution of the device in pixel per millimeter.
A special floating point value of +infinity here indicates \"unknown\", i.e. at the time of rendering undetermined or possibly infinite resolution along the corresponding direction.

methods.name: getPhysicalSize
desc: Query the physical dimensions of the device in millimeter.
A special floating point value of +infinity here indicates \"unknown\", i.e. at the time of rendering undetermined or possibly infinite resolution along the corresponding direction.

methods.name: hasFullScreenMode
desc: Tells whether this graphic device has a full screen mode, i.e.
whether a window can cover the whole screen exclusively.
